verification_notes: The step is mathematically correct under standard assumptions. Since \(S_n(\lambda)\) is finite (permutations of \(n\) distinct parts), and \(q(\eta,\eta')=\sum_j (1/x_j)\Pr(\eta\to\eta'\mid\text{bell at }j)\), each off-diagonal rate is a finite sum of nonnegative terms, hence nonnegative and finite if each \(x_j\in(0,\infty)\). With \(q(\eta,\eta)=-\sum_{\eta'\neq\eta}q(\eta,\eta')\), rows sum to zero and diagonal entries are nonpositive, so this is a valid finite-state CTMC generator; exit rates are finite (bounded by \(\sum_j 1/x_j\)). Also, because parts are distinct and \(\lambda_n=0\), the value 0 appears exactly once, so each state has exactly one species-0 site (one vacancy).

verification_notes: The uniqueness conclusion is only conditionally valid. On a finite CTMC, irreducibility implies a unique stationary distribution; that part is standard. The gap is the irreducibility argument: showing a positive-rate k=1 vacancy-adjacent swap does not by itself prove these moves generate all of S_n(\lambda). On a ring, vacancy-only adjacent swaps can preserve nontrivial invariants (e.g., cyclic order of non-vacancy labels, or orientation constraints if motion is one-sided), so connectivity of the full state space is not established from the stated argument alone.
